item.title: George Floyd murder: Derek Chauvin sentenced to over 22 years
item.description: Derek Chauvin was convicted last month of killing Mr Floyd, whose death sparked global protests.

item.title: Matt Hancock affair: Health secretary apologises for breaking social distancing guidelines
item.description: Boris Johnson stands by the health secretary after calls for him to be sacked over affair with colleague.

item.title: Euro 2020: 'Gloves off' for Wales against Denmark in last 16, says Robert Page
item.description: The "gloves are off" for Wales as they prepare to face Denmark in their Euro 2020 last-16 tie in Amsterdam on Saturday.

item.title: Glasgow MP moved to police safe house after death threat
item.description: Carol Monaghan wants better protection for public figures after online abuse turned into a "credible" death threat.

item.title: Mo Farah falls short in Tokyo Olympics qualification bid at British Championships
item.description: Four-time Olympic champion Mo Farah will consider his future after failing to qualify for this year's Games.

item.title: Czech Republic: 'Apocalyptic' scenes after tornado
item.description: Footage shows the tornado tearing through part of the Czech Republic and the devastation left behind.

item.title: Germany passes new citizenship law for descendants of Nazi victims
item.description: The move closes loopholes that denied citizenship to some whose ancestors had fled persecution.

item.title: Colin Pitchfork: Government to ask for review of child killer's release
item.description: The Parole Board will be asked to look again at its decision to free child killer Colin Pitchfork.

item.title: Nico Ali Walsh: Muhammad Ali's grandson signs pro deal with Bob Arum
item.description: The grandson of Muhammad Ali will make his professional debut on 14 August after signing with promoter Bob Arum.

item.title: Colombia President Iván Duque's helicopter hit by gunfire
item.description: Iván Duque says his aircraft was shot while he was flying near the border with Venezuela.

item.title: UFO report: US 'has no explanation' for sightings
item.description: A Pentagon report says it can only explain one of 144 sightings made by the US military since 2004.

item.title: German knife attack: Three dead and five wounded in Würzburg
item.description: A Somali man arrested after the attack had been mentally unstable recently, police say.

item.title: Dartmoor: Wistman's Wood visitors asked to stay out to protect woodland
item.description: Natural England says visitors to Wistman's Wood should allow it to "remain a special place".

item.title: The Papers: Hancock hangs on - but will it be 'Barnard Castle moment?'
item.description: Saturday's papers are dominated by the pictures and fallout of the health secretary kissing an aide.

item.title: Miami building collapse: What happened, and how quickly?
item.description: Maps, images and graphics of what we know about a 12-storey residential building's collapse north of Miami.

item.title: Katty Kay: How 100 days turned into five years of fun
item.description: Katty Kay leaves the BBC after nearly three decades of service, including five years on Beyond 100 Days.

item.title: Scientists hail stunning 'Dragon Man' discovery
item.description: Chinese researchers unveil an ancient skull that could belong to a completely new species of human.

item.title: Why has the sea off Scotland turned turquoise?
item.description: The vivid turquoise colour of the sea off the west coast looks like holiday snaps from the Mediterranean.

item.title: Covid-19: Hancock admits breaching guidelines, and travel bookings surge
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Friday evening.

item.title: Christmas returns to Penkhull pub after Covid-hit festivities
item.description: Landlord Allan Webb says like many pubs he missed out on crucial Christmas income.

item.title: Nine-year-old Flora Rider scoops world marmalade title
item.description: Flora is crowned Best in Show for her preserve, which she describes as a "little pot of sunshine".

item.title: Is Windows 11 the beginning of the end for Skype?
item.description: Windows 11 will not have Skype installed by default - favouring Microsoft Teams instead.

item.title: The Crown: Trainspotting's Jonny Lee Miller to play Sir John Major
item.description: Jonny Lee Miller swaps Trainspotting's Sick Boy for portraying the 1990s prime minister in The Crown.

item.title: The police rape interview that shocked 1980s Britain
item.description: A BBC film showing police aggressively questioning a woman caused uproar in Britain in 1982.

item.title: Covid: Prof Jonathan Van-Tam vaccinates Boston United players
item.description: The deputy chief medical officer meets his heroes as he jabs players from his beloved Boston United.

item.title: Matt Hancock: How did health secretary break Covid restrictions?
item.description: Matt Hancock admits breaching social distancing guidelines after newspaper prints photos of him and an aide embracing.

item.title: Love Island: What I wish I’d known before entering the villa
item.description: From which pyjamas to wear to getting therapy when things go wrong, ex-islanders share their tips.

item.title: Ed Sheeran: Fatherhood made me change my bad habits
item.description: The star says he's given up unhealthy ways of working since his daughter Lyra was born.

item.title: India's opinionated feminist and her viral wedding ad
item.description: The BBC speaks to those behind an Indian matrimonial ad seeking a "non-farting, non-burping, rich man".

item.title: The valuable car part gone in 60 seconds
item.description: Why international criminal networks are behind a jump in the theft of catalytic converters.

item.title: Henriett and Mihrican: The missed chances to identify a killer
item.description: A BBC investigation reveals police failings before Henriett Szucs and Mihrican Mustafa were killed.

item.title: Covid: How do you feel about going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions are set to lifted, how do people feel about going back to the office

item.title: Nicaragua's fragile leader and his ruthless crackdown on rivals
item.description: Critics say the arrests of presidential hopefuls in Nicaragua reflect President Ortega's insecurity.

item.title: UK's departing spy tech chief: We're at serious risk if we lose edge
item.description: Science is transforming espionage and many countries are taking advantage, says Prof Finkelstein.

item.title: JP Saxe: How writing about the apocalypse changed my life
item.description: JP Saxe's career changed with the release of If The World Was Ending - and so did his love life.

item.title: Illegal gold miners stalk Amazon as authorities look away
item.description: Indigenous villages say they are under attack, as illegal mining and armed violence in the jungle rise.

item.title: Harry Kane: England striker has had no contact with Tottenham over future while at Euro 2020
item.description: Harry Kane says he has held no discussions over his future at Tottenham while on duty with England at Euro 2020.

item.title: Wane's first game in charge of England ends in defeat
item.description: Shaun Wane's tenure as England boss begins in disappointment with a 26-24 defeat by the Combined All Stars.

item.title: Why Ineos are facing their toughest Tour as they try to reclaim yellow
item.description: Ineos Grenadiers as underdogs? All the money and talent may not bring success back to cycling's best-backed team.

item.title: Women's international: England 60-0 Wales - 10 different try-scorers for hosts
item.description: England's women's side warm up for this year's World Cup with a 60-0 thrashing of Wales, who were competing in their first international Test.

item.title: Wimbledon 2021: Great Britain's Katie Swan beats Australia's Arina Rodionova in qualifier
item.description: Watch the best shots as Great Britain's Katie Swan secures a straight sets victory over Australia's Arina Rodionova to reach the main draw at Wimbledon.

item.title: Watch: We've always had the same gameplan - Rice
item.description: Declan Rice talks England's gameplan as they prepare to face Germany, missing his 'bestie' Mason Mount and Twitter interactions with Toni Kroos.

item.title: Euro 2020: Wales to be ruthless against neutrals' favourites Denmark
item.description: Wales were loved at Euro 2016 but on Saturday they will be ruthless against Denmark, the neutrals' heroes of Euro 2020.

item.title: Euro 2020: Lawro takes on BBC Radio 5 Live pundits, presenters and commentators to predict the last-16 matches
item.description: BBC Sport's football expert Mark Lawrenson takes on BBC Radio 5 Live pundits, presenters and commentators to make his predictions for the last-16 ties at Euro 2020.

item.title: Euro 2020: Reviewing the boots worn by Griezmann, Sterling, Pogba & Ronaldo
item.description: Football boots expert JayMike dials in from Denmark to talk BBC Sport's Liam Loftus through the football boots making their mark at Euro 2020.

item.title: Euro 2020: Phil Foden explains England's preparations for penalties
item.description: England's Phil Foden explains how the players are preparing for the possibility of a penalty shootout with Germany in the last 16 of Euro 2020.

item.title: Euro 2020: England v Germany - pick your Three Lions starting XI
item.description: England topped their group at Euro 2020 with two wins and a draw - now who would you pick for their last-16 game against Germany?

item.title: Euro 2020 and Covid: How can I watch with my friends?
item.description: Covid rules are making things a bit different for Euro 2020 spectators.

item.title: Travel guide to Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as almost 44 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Vaccine passports: How can I prove I've had both my Covid jabs?
item.description: People who've had both Covid jabs may soon be able to avoid quarantine after travel.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: The government is considering allowing double vaccinated adults to avoid quarantine after travel.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but could the rules change as lockdown eases further?

item.title: Covid: How is furlough changing and when will it end?
item.description: Furlough has been extended until the end of September

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over-18s can get a first jab in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, and second jabs are being brought forward.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Can we stop worrying about high case numbers?
item.description: As vaccination reduces serious illness from Covid-19, the Scottish government is changing its strategy.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Medical teams around the world are learning which medicines work best against Covid.

item.title: Covid: How is Europe lifting lockdown restrictions?
item.description: Europe is gradually easing lockdown measures ahead of the tourist season.

item.title: Euro 2020: Why are England players self-isolating?
item.description: Two England players are self-isolating after a Scotland player tested positive for Covid.

item.title: Covid: Ivermectin to be studied as possible treatment in UK
item.description: Scientists begin to give the drug to people at home with symptoms to see if it can keep them out of hospital.

item.title: A fake wedding, and a $250,000 scam
item.description: How a British man's dreams of a future with his Ukrainian fiancee ended in financial disaster.

item.title: Gary Allen: The killer who nearly got away with murder
item.description: Gary Allen's conviction for the murders of two women brings a 20-year quest for justice to an end.

item.title: Wimbledon: Roger Federer's epic victory over Pete Sampras, 20 years on
item.description: At Wimbledon in 2001, a teenage hopeful took on the serial champion. It was a match for the ages - the only time two greats met.

item.title: The Lazarus heist: How North Korea almost pulled off a billion-dollar hack
item.description: In 2016 North Korean hackers planned a $1bn raid on Bangladesh's national bank and came within an inch of success. But how did they do it?

item.title: Daniel Morgan: Last chance for family in Britain's most-investigated, unsolved murder
item.description: The death of Daniel Morgan is Britain's most investigated unsolved murder. His family believe police corruption, and reluctance to confront it, could explain the murder and the failed investigations
